citations.narrative:
There are multiple areas of rust in the primary enclosures, as well as several trim boards that have been chewed
exposing bare wood in some enclosures. Rust and bare wood cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized, exposing the
animals to disease hazards. The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials
that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized.

Dust, fly strike, cob webs, dead flies, mouse droppings and other organic debris has accumulated on various surfaces
within the housing facility. Such accumulations may harbor disease hazards. All surfaces of housing facilities must be
cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted husbandry standards and practices.

The exercise yard contains piles of discarded and stored items, such as firewood, cement blocks, and other various
miscellaneous items. The vegetation in the yard is approximately 12 inches tall or more, so not everything can be readily
seen. Such materials are an injury risk to the dogs. The exercise yard must be designed and constructed of suitable
materials so it is structurally sound, kept in good repair, and protects the animals from injury.
This is a 1st re-license inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Alexandra Calderon, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.1(c)(1) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are multiple areas of rust in the primary enclosures, as well as several trim boards that have been chewed 
exposing bare wood in some enclosures. Rust and bare wood cannot be effectively cleaned and sanitized, exposing the 
animals to disease hazards. The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials 
that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized. 
3.1(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Dust, fly strike, cob webs, dead flies, mouse droppings and other organic debris has accumulated on various surfaces 
within the housing facility. Such accumulations may harbor disease hazards. All surfaces of housing facilities must be 
cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted husbandry standards and practices. 
3.6(a) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The exercise yard contains piles of discarded and stored items, such as firewood, cement blocks, and other various 
miscellaneous items. The vegetation in the yard is approximately 12 inches tall or more, so not everything can be readily 
seen. Such materials are an injury risk to the dogs. The exercise yard must be designed and constructed of suitable 
materials so it is structurally sound, kept in good repair, and protects the animals from injury. 
 
This is a 1st re-license inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

Additional Inspectors: 
Alexandra Calderon, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
